text.top: A long time ago, people made up letters so they could write.
But the only way to make a copy was to write it down again.
text.bottom: This took a long time.

text.top: If only there were a better way…
This is Johannes Gutenberg.
text.bottom: He has an idea.

text.top: He makes metal blocks with letters on the ends.
Then he puts lots of letter blocks into a machine.
text.bottom: He puts ink on the blocks and presses them onto a piece of paper.

text.top: The paper has words on it!
Now he can put in another piece of paper.
It has the same words!
Johannes has invented a machine for making copies.
text.bottom: A printing press!

text.top: That seems useful.
text.bottom: What could go wrong?

text.top: Most people in Europe were Christians.
That means they prayed to Jesus Christ.
They learned what Jesus said from a book called the Bible.
text.bottom: The Bible was in Latin. Many Latin Bibles were made with the new printing press.

text.top: Most people did not know how to read Latin.
text.bottom: So they asked their priests to read it for them.

text.top: And the boss of all priests was the Pope in Rome.
His name is Pope Leo the Tenth.
text.bottom: Hi Leo!

text.top: This is Martin Luther. He is a theologian.
text.bottom: That means he studies the Bible.

text.top: He is not happy about the Pope.
text.bottom: He has a list of complaints.

text.top: He is nailing them to the church door.
Uh oh, Martin.
text.bottom: That is not good for the door.

text.top: Martin Luther makes more than one copy of his complaints.
text.bottom: He uses a printing press to make lots of copies.

text.top: People from all over Europe read them.
Pope Leo is very mad.
So is his friend, Charles the Fifth.
text.bottom: (Charles the Fifth was an Emperor. That means he was very important.)

text.top: Leo and Charles want Martin to take back the things he said.
But Martin says “Here I Stand.”
text.bottom: He will not back down.

text.top: Charles wants to punish Martin.
Before he can do that, some robbers show up and grab Martin.
text.bottom: Oh no!

text.top: But wait! Those aren't robbers.
text.bottom: They are Martin’s friends.

text.top: Martin hides in a castle.
text.bottom: He has time to think.

text.top: Martin thinks that if people could read the Bible, they would agree with Martin.
text.bottom: But people can't read the Bible because it is in Latin.

text.top: Martin writes down a copy of the Bible in German.
text.bottom: Lots of people can read German.

text.top: He prints lots of copies of the Bible in German.
text.bottom: Lots of people read it.

text.top: When people read the Bible, a lot of them decide they do not want to listen to the Pope.
text.bottom: They are called “Protestants.”

text.top: This is Henry.
text.bottom: They call him Henry the Eighth.

text.top: He is the king of England.
text.bottom: Hi Henry!

text.top: Henry is married to Catherine.
text.bottom: She is Charles’s aunt. Hi Catherine!

text.top: Henry is not happy with Catherine.
text.bottom: He asks the new Pope if he can un-marry her.

text.top: Charles does not want Henry to un-marry his aunt.
The new Pope does not want to make Charles mad.
text.bottom: He tells Henry “no.”

text.top: Henry is mad.
text.bottom: So Henry makes his own Church.

text.top: It is called the Church of England.
text.bottom: Henry is the boss of the Church of England.

text.top: Henry un-marries Catherine and marries Anne Boleyn instead.
Good luck Anne!
text.bottom: It is not easy to be married to Henry.

text.top: This is John Calvin. Hi John!
text.bottom: He is a theologian like Martin.

text.top: He likes some of Martin’s ideas.
text.bottom: But he has some other ideas too.

text.top: He says people should not wear fancy clothes.
text.bottom: He says people should not dance.

text.top: He makes a lot of rules.
text.bottom: Some people like his ideas. They are called “Calvinists.”

text.top: Lots of people in Germany liked Martin’s ideas.
Lots of other people liked the Pope.
text.bottom: Charles liked the Pope.

top.left: There were many fights between Charles and the Protestants.

text.top: They get together and agree to stop fighting.
They agree that some places in Germany can be Catholic.
text.bottom: That means they follow the Pope.

text.top: Other places in Germany can be Lutheran.
text.bottom: That means they follow Martin.

text.top: Calvinism is still not allowed.
They all stop fighting.
text.bottom: For a little while, anyways.
